Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics and Self-Assembly in Block Copolymer Micelles for Tailored Cargo Delivery

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1437831/1437767

Micelles are tiny self-assembled capsules that can be customized for a variety of technological applications, including carrying drug molecules to a specific location inside the body as well as cleaning up environmental spills. Micelles can be composed of molecules made of two kinds of linked polymer chains, called block copolymers. Micelle behaviors can be finely tuned by changing the molecular structure of the block copolymers, and thus purposely designing the uptake amounts and release rates of interior compounds (such as drugs). This collaborative project explores the structure of block copolymer micelles as well as the block copolymer motions. By combining advanced analysis methods, the investigators will determine how the micelle-encapsulated compounds affect micelle structure and motions, and the exchange of compounds between micelles and their surroundings. This information will help scientists and engineers precisely formulate micelles for new applications in drug delivery, advanced lubrication, oil extraction, personal care products and other industries.

This project aims to systematically examine the effects of small molecule additives, co-solvents, and encapsulated drug molecules, on the structure and dynamics of block copolymer micelles. Targeted model additives (tetrahydrofuran and doxorubicin) will be employed to uncover the influence of such additives on micelle structure and dynamics. Small angle neutron scattering and multi-modal nuclear magnetic resonance will be used to investigate the effects of additive-polymer interactions on micelle equilibrium structure, polymer chain and micelle dynamics, and release rates of encapsulated compounds. The combination of these techniques will provide a comprehensive picture of key micellar dimensions and highly specific dynamical information including free unimer exchange kinetics, block and polymer chain dynamics, micelle diffusion processes, detailed solvent dynamics and exchange of additives in and out of micelles, and rates of fission and fusion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micelle systems, formed through the spontaneous self-assembly of molecules, are fascinating materials with a wide variety of potential applications as drug delivery vehicles, nanoreactors, and other nano-sized compartments. Polymeric micelles are of particular interest as they are generally more robust than surfactant-based micelles and their characteristics are easy to manipulate. There are still many features of polymeric micelles which are difficult to probe and quantify, and significant open questions remain regarding the dynamics, molecular exchange, and structure of these classes of micelles. In this project, a unique approach employing nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) has been undertaken to explore open fundamental questions on the effect of a small molecule additive (e.g. a drug or other species encapsulated within the micelle) on micelle structural characteristics and dynamic behavior.

In the first phase of this project, the effect of a solvent additive, tetrahydrofuran, on the micelle structure was explored. The solvent was found to partition within the micelle core, and modify the self-assembly behavior of the micelles, namely the aggregation number (number of molecules associated within a micelle) and overall micelle size. Furthermore, the presence of this additive impacted the distribution of polymer molecules within micelles and as free chains in solution (i.e. unimers). This partitioning of polymer chains was also explored as a function of temperature – both increasing temperature and increasing the concentration of the solvent additive were routes to increasing the number of unimers present in the solution.  These results on a model system highlight the significant impact of small molecule additives on the structural properties of polymer micelles, highly relevant to applications, such as drug delivery vehicles or nanoreactors, in which the encapsulated species may yield significant influence over the micelle self-assembly. Further, these results demonstrate the ability to tune micelle self-assembly, which is critical for applications. In the second phase of this project, model drug molecules were encapsulated into polymer micelles. The relative partitioning of the drug into the micelle core was strongly influenced by its degree of hydrophobicity, and the polymer concentration. The impact of the drug on the micelle size parameters was also examined, showing considering swelling at room temperature of the micelle core in the presence of the drug. Surprisingly, the presence of the drug had little impact on the micelle size at elevated temperatures.

Concurrently, a new and simple to employ time-resolved NMR relaxation experiment was demonstrated that can probe single chain exchange processes in micelles, with promise for replacing expensive and facility-time-limited time-resolved SANS experiments. This new NMR method can be conducted on essentially any solution NMR instrument, greatly accelerating the number of samples that can be examined by micelle researchers worldwide. Additionally, fluorescent dyes were incorporated into micelles as model cargo, allowing for characterization of cargo exchange and cargo release rates with fluorescence spectroscopy.

The results of this project provide critical knowledge to engender new applications and new formulations for practical uses in, e.g., drug delivery, advanced lubrication, oil extraction, and personal care products. Furthermore, these results have been integrated into activities for K-12 students and the general public through the Materials Day at UH, KidsTech University, Virginia Science Festival, and Houston Energy Day events, and into laboratory demonstrations and activities for undergraduate students, leveraging programs with Houston Community college.


Last Modified: 05/31/2018
Modified by: Megan L Robertson
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Micelle systems, formed through the spontaneous self-assembly of molecules, are fascinating materials with a wide variety of potential applications as drug delivery vehicles, nanoreactors, and other nano-sized compartments. Polymeric micelles are of particular interest as they are generally more robust than surfactant-based micelles and their characteristics are easy to manipulate. The results of this project provide critical knowledge to engender new applications and new formulations for practical uses in, e.g., drug delivery, advanced lubrication, oil extraction, and personal care products. Furthermore, these results have been integrated into activities for K-12 students and the general public through the Materials Day at UH, KidsTech University, Virginia Science Festival, and Houston Energy Day events, and into laboratory demonstrations and activities for undergraduate students, leveraging programs with Houston Community college.
